acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute
acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: It was classified into Category 1 from 96 hours LC50=0.028mg/L of the fish (Rainbow Trout) (CERI Hazard Data, 2002).

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on the rabbit LD50 (dermal route) value of 6.8mg/kg (CICAD 61 ( 2004)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "liquid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 value of 50.2ppm (4 hours), calculated from the testing data of rat LC50 (inhalation of vapour: GHS definition) of 142ppm (30 minutes) (CERI Hazard Data 2001-38 (2002)), was lower than 90% of the saturated vapour concentration (9,980ppm) under a saturated vapour pressure of 98.9kPa (742 mmHg, 25degC) (CERI Hazard Data 2001-38 (2002)), the substance was considered as "vapour containing substantially no mist" and was classified based on standard values expressed in ppm.

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 4.2mg/kg (CICAD 61 (2004)).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_statement: Very toxic to aquatic life with long lasting effects
chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Since acute toxicity was Category 1 and an underwater action and bio-accumulation were unknown, it was classified into Category 1.

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: No data available. Those containing stabilizers  (water content: less than 3% by mass) are classified into Class 3 and Division 6.1 (UN#1051) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: The flash point is -18degC (c.c.) and the boiling point is 26degC (ICSC, 2003). Those containing stabilizers (water content: less than 3% by mass) are classified into Class 3 and Division 6.1 (UN#1051) by the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods.

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the absence of data on multi-generation mutagenicity tests, germ/somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and germ/somatic cell genotoxicity tests in vivo, and no strong positive data on mutagenicity tests in vitro (several indices), described in CERI Hazard Data (2002) and CICAD 61 (2004).

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Organic compounds containing no oxygen, fluorine and chlorine

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Not pyrophoric when in contact with air at ordinary temperatures: the auto-ignition temperature is 538degC (ICSC, 2003)

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "liquid" according to GHS definition

self_heating_substances.rationale: Test methods applicable to liquid substances are not available

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Clinical effects described in some human case reports include "IRRITATION OF EYE, CONJUNCTIVITIS" (HSDB, 2005); "There may also be irritation from skin and eye contact with the liquid" (HSDB, 2005)). However, neither is the description of test results, and the severity of effects is not provided. Although classified into Category 2A-2B, it should be placed in Category 2A from the viewpoint of safety, if further subclassification is needed.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Clinical effects described in some case reports include "mild skin burns" in test animals (CICAD 61, 2004) and "skin irritation" in humans (HSDB, 2005). However, neither is the description of test results, and there is a provision that the substance "may be" irritating. Given these uncertainties, it was decided not to use these specific observations for classification.

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Containing no metals or metalloids (B, Si, P, Ge, As, Se, Sn, Sb, Te, Bi, Po, At)

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (central nervous system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "abnormalities in the scores of long term memory, visual ability, visual learning, psychomotor functions" (CICAD 61 (2004)) and "headache, debility, dysgeusia and dysosmia" (IRIS (2002)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, respiratory system, heart)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, respiratory system, heart)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "coma" (HSDB (2000)), "dizziness, hypopnea, sense of instability, headache and nausea" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and the evidence from animal studies including "mild adverse effects on the central nervous system" (CICAD 61 (2004)), "dyspnea, bradycardia, arrhythmia, abnormal T wave during the diastolic period, clouding of consciousness and interruption of breathing, EEG fluctuations, dyspnea, coma, debility, gait disturbance and spasm" (CERI Hazard Data 2001-38 (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
